"Zinatenga nsembe zambiri kuti nditsimikizire banja langa ndi anthu kuti Im monga wabwino, ngati si bwino, monga anzanga achimuna."

en: Journalism appealed to her because the story of the Middle East has often been told by male journalists, both local and foreign.
ny: Utolankhani unamusangalatsa chifukwa nkhani ya ku Middle East nthawi zambiri yafotokozedwa ndi atolankhani achimuna, am'deralo komanso akunja.

en: "The narrative hasnt changed because of that, but if local and international women journalists get a real chance to tell the story of the Middle East, that narrative could change, which would affect the way others see this region," Abbas said.
ny: "Nkhaniyi sinasinthe chifukwa cha zimenezo, koma ngati atolankhani azimayi am'deralo komanso a m'mayiko ena atapeza mwayi weniweni wofotokoza nkhani ya ku Middle East, nkhani imeneyo ikhoza kusintha, zomwe zingakhudze momwe ena akuwonera dera lino," adatero Abbas.

en: Sancha also believes women in journalism have an impact on the way issues are viewed in the region, including post-traumatic stress disorder and the effect it has on female health, and subjects such as violence and alcohol.
ny: Sancha amakhulupiriranso kuti azimayi mu utolankhani ali ndi zotsatira pa momwe nkhani zimawonedwera m'deralo, kuphatikizapo matenda osokoneza bongo komanso zotsatira zake pa thanzi la akazi, komanso nkhani monga chiwawa ndi mowa.

en: "We talk about all these issues that men normally wouldnt not speak about," she said.
ny: "Tikulankhula za nkhani zonsezi zomwe amuna mwachizolowezi sangalankhule," adatero.

en: Iran's Guards Commander Says Israel Creating Conditions for Own Destruction
ny: Mtsogoleri wa Alonda a Iran Akuti Israeli Akupanga Mikhalidwe Yowonongeka Yokha

en: Israel's actions are creating conditions for its own destruction, Irans Revolutionary Guards commander on Friday told a Jerusalem Day rally at which the countrys new domestically-made Kheibar Buster missile was displayed.
ny: Zochita za Israeli zikupanga mikhalidwe yowononga yokha, mtsogoleri wa Irans Revolutionary Guards Lachisanu adauza msonkhano wa Tsiku la Yerusalemu pomwe dziko latsopano lopangidwa ndi Kheibar Buster missile linawonetsedwa.

en: State television said millions of Iranians joined rallies marking Quds Day, the Arabic name for Jerusalem, in state-organized marches across the country.
ny: Wailesi yakanema ya boma inati anthu mamiliyoni ambiri a ku Iran adagwirizana ndi misonkhano yokumbukira Tsiku la Quds, dzina la Chiarabu la Yerusalemu, mu maulendo okonzedwa ndi boma kudutsa dziko.

en: It showed the Israeli flag being set on fire and groups of people around the country shouting choreographed "Death to America, Death to Israel" slogans.
ny: Inasonyeza mbendera ya Israeli ikuyikidwa pamoto ndi magulu a anthu kuzungulira dziko lonse lapansi akufuula choreographed "Imfa ku America, Imfa ku Israel" mawu.

en: Supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said in a televised speech that anti-Israeli protests and attacks showed that Palestinians rejected compromises by Arab authorities with Israel.
ny: Mtsogoleri wamkulu Ayatollah Ali Khamenei adanena m'mawu a pa wailesi yakanema kuti zionetsero zotsutsana ndi Israeli komanso kuukira kunasonyeza kuti anthu a ku Palestine anakana kuvomereza kwa akuluakulu a Arab ndi Israel.

en: Opposition to Israel is a touchstone of belief for Iran, which backs Palestinian and Lebanese Islamist militant groups opposed to peace with Israel, which Tehran does not recognize.
ny: Kutsutsa israel ndi mwala woyeserera chikhulupiriro kwa Iran, yomwe imathandizira magulu ankhondo a Palestina ndi Lebanon a Islamist omwe amatsutsa mtendere ndi Israel, omwe Tehran samazindikira.

en: "What has happened in Palestine in recent years annuls all plans for compromise with the Zionist enemy (Israel) because no plan for Palestine can be implemented in the absence or contrary to the opinions of its owners, the Palestinians," Khamenei said, speaking in Arabic and addressing Palestinians and other Arabs.
ny: "Zomwe zachitika ku Palestina m'zaka zaposachedwapa zimachotsa mapulani onse ogwirizana ndi mdani wa Zionist (Israel) chifukwa palibe ndondomeko ya Palestina yomwe ingagwiritsidwe ntchito popanda kapena mosiyana ndi malingaliro a eni ake, a Palestina," adatero Khamenei, akulankhula m'Chiarabu ndikulankhula ndi a Palestina ndi Aluya ena.

en: Thus, Khamenei said, all previous peace agreements -- such as the 1993 Oslo Accords, the two-state solution to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and former U.S. President Donald Trump's plan dubbed the Deal of the Century "are null and void".
ny: Choncho, Khamenei adati, mapangano onse amtendere akale - monga 1993 Oslo Accords, njira yothetsera maboma awiri kuti athetse nkhondo ya Israeli-Palestine, ndi ndondomeko ya Pulezidenti wakale wa United States Donald Trump yotchedwa Deal of the Century "ndi yopanda pake".

en: President Ebrahim Raisi, Irans military commanders and senior officials also attended the rallies in which people were allowed to march through the streets, the first time since the outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic two years ago.
ny: Purezidenti Ebrahim Raisi, akuluakulu a asilikali a Iran komanso akuluakulu akuluakulu adapezekanso pamisonkhano yomwe anthu adaloledwa kuyenda m'misewu, nthawi yoyamba kuyambira pamene mliri wa coronavirus unabuka zaka ziwiri zapitazo.

en: Iran's Jerusalem Day rallies are held annually in support of Palestinians, who want East Jerusalem as the capital of a future state in territories captured by Israel in a 1967 war, on the last Friday of the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan.
ny: Misonkhano ya Tsiku la Yerusalemu ya Iran imachitika chaka chilichonse pothandizira anthu a ku Palestina, omwe akufuna kuti East Jerusalem akhale likulu la dziko lamtsogolo m'madera omwe alandidwa ndi Israel mu nkhondo ya 1967, Lachisanu lomaliza la mwezi wa kusala kudya kwa Asilamu wa Ramadan.

en: "Stop your vicious deeds. You know well that we are people of action and reaction," Revolutionary Guards commander Hossein Salami, addressing Israel, told demonstrators in Tehran.
ny: "Lekani ntchito zanu zankhanza. Mukudziwa bwino kuti ndife anthu ochitapo kanthu komanso ochitapo kanthu," mtsogoleri wa Revolutionary Guards Hossein Salami, polankhula ndi Israel, adauza zionetsero ku Tehran.

en: "Our responses are painful. You create conditions for your own destruction. We will not leave you alone ...You know better than me what will befall you if you take evil action."
ny: "Mayankho athu ndi opweteka. Mumapanga mikhalidwe ya chiwonongeko chanu. Sitidzakusiyani nokha ... Mukudziwa bwino kuposa ine zimene zidzakugwerani ngati mutachitapo kanthu koipa."

en: Iran's military has vowed to retaliate harshly against any attack by Israel, which has often voiced concern over the Iranian nuclear program. Tehran says the program is for peaceful purposes only.
ny: Gulu lankhondo la Iran lalumbira kubwezera mwankhanza kuukira kulikonse kwa Israel, komwe nthawi zambiri kwafotokoza nkhawa pa pulogalamu ya nyukiliya ya Iran. Tehran ikuti pulogalamuyi ndi yamtendere yokha.

en: Israel, whose existence the Islamic Republic does not recognize, has long threatened military action against Iran if talks between Tehran and world powers fail to curb Iranian nuclear activity. Iran says its nuclear ambitions are peaceful.
ny: Israel, yomwe kukhalapo kwake Republic Islamic sikuzindikira, kwa nthawi yaitali yawopseza zochita zankhondo zotsutsana ndi Iran ngati zokambirana pakati pa Tehran ndi maulamuliro apadziko lonse zikulephera kuletsa ntchito ya nyukiliya ya Iran. Iran ikuti zolinga zake za nyukiliya ndi zamtendere.

en: In February, the Islamic Republic unveiled its "Kheibar Buster" missile with a range of 1,450 km (900 miles).
ny: Mu February, Islamic Republic inatulutsa zida zake za "Kheibar Buster" zokhala ndi mtunda wa makilomita 1,450 (900 miles).

en: Iran, which has one of the biggest missile programs in the Middle East, says its ballistic missiles have a range of up to 2,000 km (1,200 miles) and are capable of reaching its arch-foe Israel and U.S. bases in the region.
ny: Iran, yomwe ili ndi imodzi mwa mapulogalamu akuluakulu a zida zankhondo ku Middle East, ikuti mabomba ake a ballistic ali ndi mtunda wa makilomita 2,000 (1,200 miles) ndipo amatha kufika ku mdani wake wamkulu Israel ndi maziko a United States m'derali.

en: Kheibar refers to an ancient Jewish oasis in the Arabian Peninsula's Hijaz region that was overrun by Muslim warriors in the 7th century.
ny: Kheibar amatanthauza malo akale achiyuda m'chigawo cha Hijaz ku Arabia chomwe chinagonjetsedwa ndi ankhondo achisilamu m'zaka za zana la 7.

en: Tehran regards its ballistic missile program as an important deterrent against the United States, Israel and other adversaries, and has rejected Western demands to halt it.
ny: Tehran ikuwona pulogalamu yake ya ballistic missile ngati choletsa chofunikira kwambiri ku United States, Israel ndi adani ena, ndipo yakana zofuna za Kumadzulo kuti aletse.

en: Over the past year, Iran and the United States have engaged in fitful, indirect talks in Vienna to revive a 2015 nuclear deal that then-President Donald Trump reneged on in 2018 and that Iran, in turn, began violating in 2019.
ny: M'chaka chathachi, Iran ndi United States adachita zokambirana zoyenera, zosakhala zachindunji ku Vienna kuti atsitsimutse mgwirizano wa nyukiliya wa 2015 womwe pa nthawiyo Purezidenti Donald Trump adatsutsa mu 2018 ndikuti Iran, nayonso, inayamba kuphwanya mu 2019.

en: Under the 2015 deal, Iran agreed to limit its nuclear program in return for relief from economic sanctions.
ny: Pansi pa mgwirizano wa 2015, Iran inavomera kuchepetsa pulogalamu yake ya nyukiliya pobwezera mpumulo ku zilango zachuma.

en: While they appeared close to resurrecting the deal in March, talks stalled over last-minute Russian demands and whether Washington might drop Iran's Revolutionary Guards from its Foreign Terrorist Organization list.
ny: Ngakhale adawoneka pafupi kuukitsa mgwirizanowu mu Marichi, zokambirana zinaima pa zofuna za Russia za mphindi yotsiriza komanso ngati Washington ikhoza kugwetsa Alonda a Revolutionary a Iran pa mndandanda wake wa Foreign Terrorist Organization.

en: As Fewer Americans Attend Church, Can Coffee Shops Fill the Void?
ny: Pamene Anthu Ochepa a ku America Amapita kutchalitchi, Kodi Masitolo a Khofi Angadzaze Chopanda Pake?

en: Churches and other houses of worship have historically played critical social and political functions in American society. But fewer people are attending religious services, and the decline of churches and other houses of worship threatens to leave a void that could potentially be filled by coffee shops.
ny: Matchalitchi ndi nyumba zina zolambirira m'mbiri yakale zakhala ndi ntchito zovuta za chikhalidwe ndi ndale m'chitaganya cha America. Koma ndi anthu ochepa amene akupezeka pa mapemphero achipembedzo, ndipo kuchepa kwa matchalitchi ndi nyumba zina zolambirira kukuwopseza kusiya malo opanda kanthu amene angathe kudzaza ndi malo ogulitsira khofi.

en: "For so much of American history, the church has really been — or their congregations have really been — essential, providing an unheralded role in providing cohesion and connectedness in communities … encouraging civic engagement and political participation," says Daniel Cox, director of the Survey Center on American Life and a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute.
ny: "Kwa zambiri za mbiri ya America, tchalitchi chakhaladi - kapena mipingo yawo yakhaladi - yofunika, kupereka ntchito yosadziwika popereka mgwirizano ndi kulumikizana m'madera ... kulimbikitsa kugwirizana kwa anthu ndi kutenga nawo mbali pa ndale," akutero Daniel Cox, mkulu wa Survey Center on American Life ndi mnzake wamkulu ku American Enterprise Institute.

en: "It was not happenstance or luck that the civil rights movement emerged out of the church," Cox says.
ny: "Sichinali chochitika kapena mwayi kuti gulu la ufulu wa anthu linatuluka m'tchalitchi," Cox akutero.

en: "And you see that cross-culturally … whether it's in predominantly white rural communities, in the suburbs, wherever, churches have historically been really, really important."
ny: "Ndipo inu mukuona kuti mtanda chikhalidwe ... kaya ndi m'madera ambiri azungu akumidzi, m'madera akumidzi, kulikonse, matchalitchi m'mbiri yakale akhala ofunika kwambiri, kwenikweni."

en: Churches and other houses of worship have also played a role in helping immigrants assimilate once they arrive in America, Cox says.
ny: Matchalitchi ndi nyumba zina zolambirira zathandizanso anthu ochokera m'mayiko ena kuti adziwe bwinobwino akangofika ku America, akutero Cox.

en: In 1999, 70% of Americans said they belonged to a church, mosque or synagogue.
ny: Mu 1999, 70% ya anthu a ku America ananena kuti anali a tchalitchi, mzikiti kapena sunagoge.

en: By 2020, that number had dropped to 47%. A 2019 survey found that only about three in 10 Americans say they attend weekly religious services.
ny: Pofika 2020, chiwerengero chimenecho chinatsika kufika pa 47%. Kafukufuku wa 2019 adapeza kuti pafupifupi atatu okha mwa 10 a ku America amati amapita ku mapemphero achipembedzo mlungu uliwonse.

en: Third places  Lack of involvement and affiliation with churches, mosques and synagogues means people might be missing out on what urban sociologist Ray Oldenburg dubbed as "third places" — public gathering spots that offer something that home, the "first place," and work, the "second place," might not.
ny: Malo achitatu Kusowa kwa kukhudzidwa ndi kugwirizana ndi matchalitchi, mizikiti ndi masunagoge kumatanthauza kuti anthu angakhale akuphonya zomwe katswiri wa zachikhalidwe cha anthu a m'tawuni Ray Oldenburg adazitcha "malo achitatu" - malo osonkhanira anthu omwe amapereka chinachake chomwe kunyumba, "malo oyamba," ndi ntchito, "malo achiwiri," mwina sanga.

en: Oldenburg argued that third places are critical to a communitys social vitality.
ny: Oldenburg anatsutsa kuti malo achitatu ndi ofunika kwambiri kwa anthu a m'deralo.

en: An October 2021 survey conducted by the American Survey Center found that commercial spaces like coffee houses foster trust and connection in American communities and could help fill the void left by churches.
ny: Kafukufuku wa October 2021 wochitidwa ndi American Survey Center adapeza kuti malo ogulitsa malonda monga nyumba za khofi amalimbikitsa chidaliro ndi kulumikizana m'madera a ku America ndipo angathandize kudzaza chopanda pake chosiyidwa ndi matchalitchi.

en: "If you're a regular at a cafe, the barista may know what you usually order, and they can make it for you, and that feels good," says clinical psychologist Dr. Maria Espinola, an assistant professor in the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Neuroscience at the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine.
ny: "Ngati ndinu wokhazikika pa cafe, barista angadziwe zomwe nthawi zambiri mumalamula, ndipo akhoza kukupangirani, ndipo zimenezo zimamveka bwino," akutero katswiri wa zamaganizo Dr. Maria Espinola, pulofesa wothandizira mu Dipatimenti ya Psychiatry and Behavioral Neuroscience ku University of Cincinnati College of Medicine.

en: "It feels good to be recognized, to know that people are expecting you, to know that people care about you, to know that you belong, because the need for belonging and human connection is a fundamental need that we all have, and it's important to have that fulfilled in different ways," Espinola says.
ny: "Zimamveka bwino kuzindikiridwa, kudziwa kuti anthu akukuyembekezerani, kudziwa kuti anthu amakuganizirani, kudziwa kuti ndinu woyenera, chifukwa kufunika kokhala ndi kugwirizana kwa anthu ndikofunikira kwambiri komwe tonse tili nawo, ndipo ndikofunikira kuti zimenezo zikwaniritsidwe m'njira zosiyanasiyana," akutero Espinola.

en: "So, places like third places can allow us to do that."
ny: "Choncho, malo monga malo achitatu angatilole kuchita zimenezo."

en: In the past, churches and other houses of worship have been a third place for many Americans.
ny: M'mbuyomu, matchalitchi ndi nyumba zina zolambirira zakhala malo achitatu kwa anthu ambiri a ku America.

en: In 2019, 67% of people surveyed said they have a third place — a coffee shop, bar, restaurant, park or other place in their community that they visit regularly.
ny: Mu 2019, 67% ya anthu omwe anafunsidwa anati ali ndi malo achitatu - malo ogulitsira khofi, bar, malo odyera, paki kapena malo ena m'dera lawo omwe amapita nthawi zonse.

en: That number dropped to 56% in 2021 — a number that could have been affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.
ny: Chiwerengero chimenecho chinatsika kufika pa 56% mu 2021 - chiwerengero chomwe chikanakhudzidwa ndi mliri wa COVID-19.

en: "What we found was that people who had a third place were much more connected to their community," says Cox. "They're much more likely to engage in other activities there.
ny: "Chimene tinapeza chinali chakuti anthu omwe anali ndi malo achitatu anali ogwirizana kwambiri ndi dera lawo," akutero Cox. "Iwo nthawi zambiri amachita zinthu zina kumeneko.

en: They are much more trusting of their neighbors. There's a whole great array of positive social outcomes that were connected to having a third place … and for a lot of Americans, it's a coffee shop or a cafe."
ny: Iwo amakhulupirira kwambiri anansi awo. Pali gulu lonse lalikulu la zotsatira zabwino za chikhalidwe zomwe zinagwirizanitsidwa ndi kukhala ndi malo achitatu ... ndipo kwa anthu ambiri a ku America, ndi malo ogulitsira khofi kapena cafe."

en: What coffee shops have in their favor is that they can be found almost everywhere, all over the country, and anyone who wants to can stop by regularly.
ny: Chimene masitolo a khofi ali nacho m'chiyanjo chawo nchakuti angapezeke pafupifupi kulikonse, m'dziko lonselo, ndipo aliyense amene akufuna angaime nthaŵi zonse.

en: And many are open most days of the week.
ny: Ndipo ambiri amatsegulidwa masiku ambiri a sabata.

en: Cox says even brief coffee shop encounters can increase a sense of belonging.
ny: Cox akunena kuti ngakhale kukumana kwakanthaŵi m'sitolo ya khofi kungawonjezere lingaliro la kukhala.

en: "I think there's a lot of potential here, and a lot of it is unrealized potential," Cox says.
ny: "Ndikuganiza kuti pali zambiri zomwe zingatheke pano, ndipo zambiri ndizotheka zosadziwika," Cox akuti.

en: "But in terms of what they could do, there's a lot there.
ny: "Koma ponena za zomwe akanatha kuchita, pali zambiri kumeneko.

en: I've been in places where the same group of folks come in there to play chess.
ny: Ndakhala m'malo omwe gulu lomwelo la anthu amabwera kumeneko kudzasewera chess.

en: Or they have their informal bunch of retirees. … They just got together, and they talked and chatted and caught up with each other. … I don't know where else they would have gone — maybe a church, but maybe not — to share information, to encourage each other to maybe get involved in an activity.
ny: Kapena ali ndi gulu lawo lamwamwaŵi la opuma pantchito. ... Iwo anangosonkhana, ndipo analankhula ndi kucheza ndi kugwirizana. ... Sindikudziwa kwina kumene akanapita — mwinamwake tchalitchi, koma mwinamwake ayi — kukagawana chidziŵitso, kulimbikitsana kuti mwina aloŵe m'ntchito.

en: And I think that is what is so powerful about coffee shops."
ny: Ndipo ndikuganiza kuti ndi zimene zili zamphamvu kwambiri pa masitolo a khofi."

en: What US Mayors Are Most Worried About After the Pandemic
ny: Zomwe Meya a US Akuda Nkhawa Kwambiri Pambuyo pa Mliri

en: Americas mayors are most concerned about the lingering mental health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a nationwide survey of 126 mayors conducted during the summer of 2021.
ny: Meya a ku America akuda nkhawa kwambiri ndi zotsatira za matenda a maganizo zomwe zikukhalabe za mliri wa COVID-19, malinga ndi kafukufuku wa dziko lonse wa meya wa 126 womwe unachitika m'chilimwe cha 2021.

en: The respondents headed cities with at least 75,000 residents. The local leaders are still focused on traditional issues such as violent crime, the economy and infrastructure, but they are most concerned about the pandemics long-term impact on the mental health of their constituents.
ny: Ofunsidwawo anatsogolera mizinda yokhala ndi anthu osachepera 75,000. Atsogoleri a mderalo akuyang'anabe pa nkhani zachikhalidwe monga upandu wachiwawa, chuma ndi zomangamanga, koma akuda nkhawa kwambiri ndi miliri yomwe ikukhudza nthawi yaitali thanzi la maganizo a anthu omwe amasankha.

en: Mental health was top of mind for Michael Udine when he was sworn in as mayor of Broward County, Florida, in November 2021.
ny: Thanzi la maganizo linali pamwamba pa maganizo a Michael Udine pamene analumbira monga meya wa Broward County, Florida, mu November 2021.

en: "Everything that was a potential issue pre-pandemic has pretty much been exacerbated by the pandemic," he says. "There were issues going into the pandemic, and it was becoming more and more important on everyone's radar screen about the mental health of people of all ages. And I think the pandemic pretty much supercharged those issues."
ny: "Chirichonse chomwe chinali nkhani yomwe ingachitike mliri usanachitike chakula kwambiri ndi mliriwu," iye akutero. "Panali nkhani zomwe zikulowa mu mliriwu, ndipo zinali kukhala zofunika kwambiri pa chophimba cha radar cha aliyense chokhudza thanzi lamaganizo la anthu a misinkhu yonse. Ndipo ine ndikuganiza mliri wokongola kwambiri supercharged nkhani zimenezo."

en: It is not unusual for large outbreaks of disease to have a negative impact on mental health, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which reports that rates of anxiety and depressive disorders among adults increased during the pandemic.
ny: Si zachilendo kuti mliri waukulu wa matenda ukhudze thanzi la maganizo, malinga ndi Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, yomwe ikunena kuti kuchuluka kwa nkhawa ndi matenda ovutika maganizo pakati pa anthu akuluakulu kunawonjezeka panthawi ya mliriwu.

en: The pandemic has also adversely influenced the emotional and mental health of about one-third of Americas youth.
ny: Mliriwu wakhudzanso kwambiri thanzi la maganizo ndi maganizo a achinyamata pafupifupi gawo limodzi mwa magawo atatu a achinyamata a ku America.

en: "What we've seen is just such anxiety, kids who wouldn't ordinarily have a meltdown, because it's so much change and difficulty adjusting to transitions," Maryland psychologist Mary Karapetian Alvord told VOA last month. "We've also seen a lot more sadness and depression."
ny: "Zimene tawona ndi nkhawa zoterezi, ana omwe nthawi zambiri sangakhale ndi kusungunuka, chifukwa ndizosintha kwambiri komanso zovuta kusintha kusintha," katswiri wa zamaganizo wa Maryland Mary Karapetian Alvord adauza VOA mwezi watha. "Taonanso chisoni chachikulu komanso kuvutika maganizo."

en: Early on in the pandemic, mayors were more focused on city operations, budget shortfalls and the threat the pandemic posed to small businesses, according to David Glick, an associate professor of political science at Boston University and a co-author of the 2021 Menino Survey of Mayors.
ny: Kumayambiriro kwa mliriwu, meya ankayang'ana kwambiri pa ntchito za mzinda, kuchepa kwa bajeti komanso chiwopsezo chomwe mliriwu unapereka kwa mabizinesi ang'onoang'ono, malinga ndi David Glick, pulofesa wogwirizana ndi sayansi ya ndale ku yunivesite ya Boston komanso wolemba bungwe la 2021 Menino Survey of Mayors.

en: "Some of those concerns still remain, but what we saw more of in 2021 … is concern about some of the long-term impacts on individual residents," Glick says. "Concerns about polarization over vaccines and just people being pushed to their limits … and certainly less on their city budgets and revenues and having to cut programs and some of those types of things that were probably more top of mind earlier in the pandemic."
ny: "Zina mwa nkhawa zimenezo zidakalipobe, koma zomwe tinawona zambiri mu 2021 ... ndi nkhawa zina mwa zotsatira za nthawi yayitali kwa nzika payekha," Glick akuti. "Nkhawa za polarization pa katemera ndi anthu chabe akukankhidwa mpaka malire awo ... ndipo ndithudi zochepa pa bajeti yawo ya mzinda ndi ndalama ndikuyenera kudula mapulogalamu ndi zina mwa mitundu imeneyo ya zinthu zomwe mwina zinali pamwamba kwambiri pa maganizo kumayambiriro kwa mliriwu."

en: Over half of mayors, 52%, are worried about "lingering mental health challenges and trauma," according to the survey. Additionally, more than one-third of mayors, 37%, are worried about learning loss among young people.
ny: Oposa theka la meya, 52%, akuda nkhawa ndi "mavuto a maganizo omwe akupitirizabe komanso kupweteka," malinga ndi kafukufukuyu. Kuphatikiza apo, oposa gawo limodzi mwa magawo atatu a meya, 37%, akuda nkhawa ndi kutayika kwa kuphunzira pakati pa achinyamata.

en: "Second only to mental health and trauma, and they're probably not totally independent concerns," Glick says. "It is part of that shift of mayors concerns from immediate threats to businesses closing and people getting sick, to some of these longer-term consequences that are going to persist in the future. And learning loss among their students, theyre worried it's going to persist for many, many, many years into the future. It's hard to make up for."
ny: "Chachiwiri chokha ku thanzi la maganizo ndi kupweteka, ndipo mwina si nkhawa zodziyimira pawokha kwathunthu," Glick akuti. "Ndi gawo la kusintha kumeneko kwa nkhawa za meya kuchokera ku ziwopsezo zofulumira kuti mabizinesi atseke ndipo anthu akudwala, kupita ku zina mwa zotsatira za nthawi yayitali izi zomwe zikupitirirabe mtsogolo. Ndipo kutayika kwa kuphunzira pakati pa ophunzira awo, theyre adada nkhawa kuti zidzapitirizabe kwa zaka zambiri, zambiri, zambiri mtsogolo. N'zovuta kupanga."

en: According to the survey, other top concerns for Americas mayors include the financial insecurity of low-income residents (33%), the closing of small businesses (29%) and increased crime and violence (26%).
ny: Malinga ndi kafukufukuyu, nkhawa zina zapamwamba kwa meya a America zikuphatikizapo kupanda chitetezo cha ndalama kwa anthu osauka (33%), kutsekedwa kwa mabizinesi ang'onoang'ono (29%) ndi kuwonjezeka kwa upandu ndi chiwawa (26%).

en: Just 7% of mayors are worried about the shift to remote work and the long-term impact that could have on outmigration — people moving away from their cities.
ny: 7% yokha ya meya akuda nkhawa ndi kusintha kwa ntchito yakutali komanso zotsatira za nthawi yayitali zomwe zingakhale nazo pa outmigration - anthu akuchoka m'mizinda yawo.

en: The $350 billion in funding from the American Rescue Plan to local and state governments could help mayors address some of their concerns. The survey found that 78% of mayors believe the money will allow them to make meaningful change.
ny: Ndalama zokwana madola 350 biliyoni kuchokera ku American Rescue Plan kupita ku maboma am'deralo ndi a boma zikhoza kuthandiza meya kuthana ndi nkhawa zawo zina. Kafukufukuyu adapeza kuti 78% ya meya amakhulupirira kuti ndalamazo zidzawalola kusintha kwatanthauzo.

en: "What we're seeing is a large majority are using it for things they consider to be transformative and will make major changes to their cities," Glick says, "instead of feeling obligated or feeling the necessity to use it to plug up over-budget gaps to keep the doors open and the lights on."
ny: "Zimene tikuwona ndi ambiri akugwiritsa ntchito zinthu zomwe amaona kuti ndizosintha ndipo zidzasintha kwambiri mizinda yawo," Glick akuti, "m'malo momva kuti ali ndi udindo kapena kumva kufunika kogwiritsa ntchito kutseka mipata yowonjezera bajeti kuti zitseko zikhale zotseguka ndi magetsi."

en: Young Compete Against Old in Hottest US Rental Market in a Decade
ny: Achinyamata Amapikisana ndi Okalamba mu Msika Wotentha Kwambiri wa US Rental mu Zaka Khumi

en: Renting an apartment can be a challenge for new college graduates who are facing the hottest U.S. rental market in a decade, along with some unexpected competition from millennials — people aged 24 to 40 — and even baby boomers — the over-57 club.
ny: Kubwereka nyumba kungakhale kovuta kwa omaliza maphunziro atsopano a koleji omwe akukumana ndi msika wotentha kwambiri wa US m'zaka khumi, pamodzi ndi mpikisano wina wosayembekezereka kuchokera ku millennials - anthu azaka 24 mpaka 40 - ndipo ngakhale ana oyambira - kalabu yoposa 57.

en: "You have aging millennials who are creating families who should be moving from rental situations into ownership but, because of the lack of housing supply, that has been stopped in a lot of instances. And so, what you see is the aging millennial population continues to rent," says Doug Ressler, manager of business intelligence at Yardi-Matrix, a commercial real estate data and research firm.
ny: "Muli okalamba millennials amene akupanga mabanja amene ayenera kukhala kusuntha ku zinthu yobwereka mu umwini koma, chifukwa cha kusowa kwa nyumba, kuti waimitsidwa mu zochitika zambiri. Ndipo kotero, zomwe mukuwona ndi anthu okalamba a zaka chikwi akupitirizabe kubwereka," akutero Doug Ressler, woyang'anira nzeru zamalonda ku Yardi-Matrix, deta yogulitsa malonda ndi kampani yofufuza.

en: "It's not just about millennials, it's not just about [Gen] Z [people under 24], we also see that boomers are making a transition, he added. "Their percentage of moving into rental properties is growing in the last five years."
ny: "Si za millennials zokha, si za [Gen] Z [anthu omwe ali pansi pa 24], timaonanso kuti boomers akupanga kusintha, adawonjezera. " Chiwerengero chawo chosamukira m'nyumba zobwereka chikukula m'zaka zisanu zapitazi."

en: There are a variety of reasons older people are opting for rentals, according to Ressler.
ny: Pali zifukwa zosiyanasiyana zomwe anthu okalamba akusankha lendi, malinga ndi Ressler.

en: "They've lived in a home for so long and they want to be able to reduce their expenses on a fixed income," he says. "They want to live in a social cohort, like a retirement community, and things like that where it's much more socially amenable to them."
ny: "Iwo akhala m'nyumba kwa nthawi yaitali ndipo akufuna kuti athe kuchepetsa ndalama zomwe amawononga pa ndalama zokhazikika," iye akutero. "Iwo akufuna kukhala mu gulu chikhalidwe, ngati anthu opuma pantchito, ndi zinthu ngati zimenezo kumene kwambiri chikhalidwe amenable kwa iwo."

en: The asking price of apartment rentals was up 10.7% in September 2021 compared to last year at the same time, according to the National Association of Realtors (NAR).
ny: Mtengo wofunsira wa nyumba yobwereka nyumba unakwera 10.7% mu September 2021 poyerekeza ndi chaka chatha nthawi yomweyo, malinga ndi bungwe la National Association of Realtors (NAR).

en: "It's a hot market. We have never seen this market so hot in the last decade," says Gay Cororaton, NARs senior economist and director of housing and commercial research. "The average rent growth, year-over-year, is about 3-to-5%. We're seeing 11% rent growth now, so, clearly, way above trends weve had in the past."
ny: "Ndi msika wotentha. Sitinaonepo msika uwu wotentha kwambiri m'zaka khumi zapitazi," akutero Gay Cororaton, katswiri wa zachuma wamkulu wa NARs komanso mtsogoleri wa kafukufuku wa nyumba ndi malonda. "Kukula kwa lendi pafupifupi, chaka ndi chaka, ndi pafupifupi 3-to-5%. Tikuwona 11% lendi kukula tsopano, kotero, momveka bwino, njira pamwamba zochitika weve anali m'mbuyomu."

en: Renters are feeling the squeeze because the COVID-19 pandemic caused supply chain issues, slowing down home building in the United States. Instead of the usual 5-to-6 month supply of available single-family homes, supply dropped below two months in January 2021. The lack of housing supply means millennials are having a harder time buying a single-family home, which has been the traditional trajectory in the past.
ny: Olemba lendi akumva kupsinjika chifukwa mliri wa COVID-19 unayambitsa nkhani zothandizira, kuchepetsa nyumba ku United States. M'malo mwachizolowezi 5-to-6 mwezi kupereka nyumba zilipo banja limodzi, kupereka anatsika pansipa miyezi iwiri mu January 2021. Kusowa kwa nyumba kumatanthauza millennials akukhala ndi nthawi yovuta kugula nyumba ya banja limodzi, yomwe yakhala njira yachikhalidwe m'mbuyomu.

en: "The whole building industry was beset by supply chain issues," Cororaton says. "Shipments couldn't come in, the price of lumber was rising, manufacturing slowed, workers could not come in [to work], so you have shortages of frames, appliances. So, essentially, just a short supply."
ny: "Makampani onse omanga nyumba anali ndi nkhani zothandizira," Cororaton akuti. "Zotumiza sizinathe kulowa, mtengo wa matabwa unali kukwera, kupanga zinthu kunachepa, antchito sakanatha kubwera [kuntchito], choncho muli ndi kusowa kwa mafelemu, zipangizo zamagetsi. Choncho, kwenikweni, zochepa chabe."

en: The housing supply got even tighter during the pandemic as more investors put their money into housing, according to Cororaton, while existing homeowners looked for second homes.
ny: Kupereka nyumba kunavuta kwambiri panthawi ya mliriwu pamene ogulitsa ndalama ambiri anaika ndalama zawo m'nyumba, malinga ndi Cororaton, pamene eni nyumba omwe alipo adayang'ana nyumba zachiwiri.

en: "With the pandemic, there was also a big demand for second homes, for vacation homes. Typically, vacation homes accounted for just about 5% [of the market]," she says. "Early this summer they rose to about 8%. So again, strong demand and strong imbalance of demand and supply caused home prices to rise, made them less affordable."
ny: "Ndi mliriwu, panalinso kufunika kwakukulu kwa nyumba zachiwiri, nyumba za tchuthi. Kawirikawiri, nyumba za tchuthi zinali pafupifupi 5% [ya msika]," iye akutero. "Kuyambirira kwa chilimwe chino adakwera pafupifupi 8%. Choncho kachiwiri, kufunika kwamphamvu komanso kusagwirizana kwamphamvu kwa kufunika ndi kupereka kunapangitsa kuti mitengo ya nyumba ikwere, zinapangitsa kuti zikhale zochepa."

en: The hottest rental markets right now are in the West and South. More renters are moving to Dallas and Houston in Texas, followed by Atlanta, Georgia; New York; Los Angeles; Austin, Texas; Phoenix, Arizona; and Washington, D.C., according to NAR.
ny: Misika yotentha kwambiri yobwereka pakali pano ili ku West ndi South. Olemba lendi ambiri akusamukira ku Dallas ndi Houston ku Texas, motsatiridwa ndi Atlanta, Georgia; New York; Los Angeles; Austin, Texas; Phoenix, Arizona; ndi Washington, D.C., malinga ndi NAR.

en: Cororaton expects the coming year to be a little better but says the housing shortage is likely to continue for the next few years.
ny: Cororaton akuyembekezera kuti chaka chomwe chikubwerachi chidzakhala chabwino pang'ono koma akuti kusowa kwa nyumba kudzapitirira kwa zaka zingapo zotsatira.

en: "You know, the old adage of moving from rentals into homeownership, that whole polemic may be changing," says Ressler. "The sweet spot was always the millennials, and now the millennials are being replaced by the [Gen] Zs, but the millennials are staying longer and the Zs are coming on board, and now you've got the demographic of the boomers … What it means is a very profitable and dynamic [rental] market that's going to continue to grow."
ny: "Mukudziwa, mwambi wakale wa kusuntha kuchokera ku renti kupita ku nyumba, kuti polemic yonse ingakhale ikusintha," akutero Ressler. "Malo okoma nthawi zonse anali millennials, ndipo tsopano millennials akusinthidwa ndi [Gen] Zs, koma millennials akukhala nthawi yaitali ndipo Zs akubwera pa bolodi, ndipo tsopano muli ndi chiwerengero cha anthu a boomers ... Zomwe zikutanthauza ndi msika wopindulitsa kwambiri komanso wamphamvu [wobwereka] womwe ukupitirizabe kukula."

en: Are COVID-19 Restrictions Stunting Children’s Immune Systems?
ny: Kodi Zoletsa za COVID-19 Zikulepheretsa Chitetezo cha Mthupi cha Ana?

en: Some medical experts have expressed concern that COVID-19 preventative measures, like masking and remote schooling, are potentially weakening childrens immune systems by shielding them from the usual childhood illnesses.
ny: Akatswiri ena azachipatala awonetsa nkhawa kuti njira zopewera COVID-19, monga masking ndi maphunziro akutali, zikhoza kufooketsa chitetezo cha mthupi cha ana powateteza ku matenda a ubwana wachizolowezi.

en: "There are a lot of reasons to believe that kids need to be exposed to things to keep their immunity complex, so that should they encounter something very dangerous, they have aspects of their immunity that might cross over and help protect them against those things," says Sara Sawyer, a professor of molecular, cellular and developmental biology at the University of Colorado Boulder.
ny: "Pali zifukwa zambiri zokhulupirira kuti ana amafunika kuyang'anizana ndi zinthu kuti chitetezo chawo chikhale chovuta, choncho akakumana ndi chinthu choopsa kwambiri, amakhala ndi mbali za chitetezo chawo zomwe zingadutse ndikuthandizira kuwateteza ku zinthu zimenezo," akutero Sara Sawyer, pulofesa wa sayansi ya maselo, maselo ndi chitukuko pa yunivesite ya Colorado Boulder.

en: At birth, vulnerable infants get antibodies from their mothers breast milk, which helps protect them until they can build their own immunity.
ny: Pa kubadwa, makanda osatetezeka amapeza ma antibodies kuchokera kwa amayi awo mkaka wa m'mawere, zomwe zimathandiza kuwateteza mpaka atamanga chitetezo chawo.

en: Its no accident that babies start putting things in their mouths as soon as they gain enough dexterity to pick things up.  "They're doing that because they're sampling the environment and building their immunity. That's an evolutionary trait," Sawyer says.
ny: Its no accident that babies start putting things in their mouths as soon as they gain enough dexterity to pick things up.  "Iwo akuchita zimenezo chifukwa akuyesa chilengedwe ndi kumanga chitetezo chawo. Umenewo ndi khalidwe la chisinthiko," akutero Sawyer.

en: "Theyre exposing their body to germs in a certain, level way to build their immunity.
ny: "Theyre kuwonetsa thupi lawo ku majeremusi m'njira inayake, mlingo kumanga chitetezo chawo.

en: So, some people would argue that childhood illnesses, like colds and stomach bugs, build our immunity so that when more dangerous things come along, we're prepared and we don't get as sick from those more dangerous things."
ny: Choncho, anthu ena angatsutse kuti matenda a paubwana, monga chimfine ndi nsikidzi za m'mimba, amamanga chitetezo chathu kuti zinthu zoopsa kwambiri zikabwera, timakhala okonzeka ndipo sitidwala mofanana ndi zinthu zoopsa kwambiri zimenezo."

en: Even before the pandemic, epidemiological evidence suggested that children in more developed countries, where handwashing and the use of sanitizer are more prevalent, might have less-developed immune systems compared to kids in developing nations who are routinely exposed to more bacteria, viruses and allergens.
ny: Ngakhale mliriwu usanachitike, umboni wa matendawa unasonyeza kuti ana a m'mayiko otukuka kwambiri, kumene kusamba m'manja komanso kugwiritsa ntchito mankhwala odzola kumakhala kofala kwambiri, mwina ali ndi chitetezo cha mthupi chochepa poyerekeza ndi ana a m'mayiko osauka omwe nthawi zonse amakhala ndi mabakiteriya ambiri, mavairasi ndi allergens.

en: This makes kids in more industrialized countries more vulnerable to developing autoimmune diseases, according to whats known as the "hygiene hypothesis."
ny: Zimenezi zimapangitsa kuti ana a m'mayiko otukuka kwambiri azivutika kwambiri kudwala matenda a autoimmune, malinga ndi zomwe zimadziwika kuti "lingaliro la ukhondo."

en: "The hygiene hypothesis is actually quite controversial because it's thought that our exposure to microbes isn't the only factor," says Cody Warren, a virologist and immunologist who is a postdoctoral fellow at the University of Colorado Boulder.
ny: "Lingaliro la ukhondo kwenikweni ndi lotsutsana kwambiri chifukwa akuganiza kuti kuwonetsedwa kwathu kwa tizilombo toyambitsa matenda si chinthu chokha," akutero Cody Warren, katswiri wa virologist ndi immunologist yemwe ndi mnzake wa postdoctoral ku University of Colorado Boulder.

en: "A lot of this could also be dictated by genetics, diet, and the environment that we live in.
ny: "Zambiri mwa zimenezi zikhozanso kulamulidwa ndi majini, zakudya, ndi malo amene tikukhalamo.

en: That also shapes our immune system… it's a real multifactorial thing that we can't fully account for just by wearing masks.
ny: Zimenezo zimapanganso chitetezo chathu cha mthupi... ndi chinthu chenicheni cha multifactorial chomwe sitingathe kufotokoza mokwanira mwa kungovala masks.

en: There are other things that go into that equation."
ny: Pali zinthu zina zimene zimapita mu equation imeneyo."

en: Warren, the father of three young children, says spending lots of time outdoors is one way to balance the negatives of isolation.
ny: Warren, tate wa ana aang'ono atatu, akunena kuti kuthera nthaŵi yambiri panja ndi njira imodzi yolinganizira zoipa za kudzipatula.

en: "Just exploring microbes in the environment also is benefiting [and] training our immune system," Warren says. "Our immune systems get trained through the foods that we eat, which also have microorganisms on them.
ny: "Kungofufuza tizilombo toyambitsa matenda m'chilengedwe komanso kukupindulitsa [ndi] kuphunzitsa chitetezo chathu cha mthupi," Warren akutero. "Chitetezo chathu cha mthupi chimaphunzitsidwa kudzera mu zakudya zomwe timadya, zomwe zimakhalanso ndi tizilombo toyambitsa matenda pa iwo.

en: And so, despite the fact that we've kind of been hunkered down a little bit, I do feel that our immune systems will catch up."
ny: Ndipo kotero, ngakhale kuti ife mtundu wakhala hunkered pansi pang'ono, ine ndikuchita kumverera kuti chitetezo chathu cha m'thupi chidzagwira."

en: There are other things parents can do, he says, to boost their childrens immune systems during pandemic times.  "One of the most important things you can do is just to stay up to date on vaccines.
ny: Pali zinthu zina zomwe makolo angachite, iye akuti, kuti apititse patsogolo chitetezo cha mthupi cha ana awo panthawi ya mliri.  "Chimodzi mwa zinthu zofunika kwambiri zomwe mungachite ndikungokhala patsogolo pa katemera.

en: That's one of the best ways that we have to train our immune systems," Warren says.
ny: Imeneyo ndi imodzi mwa njira zabwino kwambiri zomwe tiyenera kuphunzitsa chitetezo chathu cha mthupi," Akutero Warren.

en: "But also, equally important is making sure our children have a good diet and they regulate stress.
ny: "Komanso, chofunika mofananamo ndi kuonetsetsa kuti ana athu ali ndi zakudya zabwino ndipo amawongolera kupsinjika.

en: It's been well documented that both of those — having a good diet, a less stressful environment — can have a positive impact on our immune system."
ny: Zalembedwa bwino kuti zonsezi - kukhala ndi zakudya zabwino, malo osapanikizika kwambiri - zingakhudze kwambiri chitetezo chathu cha mthupi."

en: Once public health officials say masks are no longer necessary, Sawyer thinks pointing out the positives of putting our masks away could reassure hesitant parents who worry about their children getting sick.
ny: Pamene akuluakulu a zaumoyo akunena kuti nyawu sizikufunikanso, Sawyer akuganiza kuti kusonyeza zabwino za kuika nyawu zathu kutali kungatsimikizire makolo ozengereza amene amada nkhaŵa ndi ana awo kudwala.

en: "Maybe we should have a public conversation about the possible reasons to take that mask off, if they are in school, and get back to the normal repertoire of relatively safe childhood illnesses," she says.
ny: "Mwinamwake tiyenera kukambirana pagulu za zifukwa zomwe zingatheke kuchotsa chigoba chimenecho, ngati ali kusukulu, ndikubwerera ku repertoire yachibadwa ya matenda otetezeka a ana," iye akutero.

en: "The plus side of childhood illnesses is that they can build up that hornet's nest of immunity that could protect kids against new things that then come along."
ny: "Mbali yowonjezera ya matenda a ubwana ndikuti akhoza kumanga chisa cha hornet chimenecho cha chitetezo chomwe chingateteze ana ku zinthu zatsopano zomwe kenako zimabwera."

en: US Quietly Expands Asylum Limits While Preparing to End Them
ny: US Mwakachetechete Ikuwonjezera Malire a Asylum Pamene Akukonzekera Kuwathetsa

en: The Biden administration has begun expelling Cubans and Nicaraguans to Mexico under pandemic-related powers to deny migrants a chance to seek asylum, expanding use of the rule even as it publicly says it has been trying to unwind it, officials said Wednesday.
ny: Ulamuliro wa Biden wayamba kuthamangitsa anthu a ku Cuba ndi a ku Nicaragua kupita ku Mexico pansi pa mphamvu zokhudzana ndi mliri kuti akane osamuka mwayi wofunafuna chitetezo, kuwonjezera kugwiritsa ntchito lamuloli ngakhale kuti limanena poyera kuti lakhala likuyesetsa kumasula, akuluakulu adati Lachitatu.

en: The U.S. struck agreement with Mexico to expel up to 100 Cubans and 20 Nicaraguans a day from three locations: San Diego; El Paso, Texas; and Rio Grande Valley, Texas, according to a U.S. official with direct knowledge of the effort.
ny: U.S. inagwirizana ndi Mexico kuti atulutse anthu a ku Cuba a 100 ndi 20 Nicaraguans patsiku kuchokera kumalo atatu: San Diego; El Paso, Texas; ndi Rio Grande Valley, Texas, malinga ndi mkulu wina wa ku United States yemwe akudziwa mwachindunji za khama limeneli.

en: The expulsions began April 27 and will end May 22, the official told The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the agreement has not been made public.
ny: Kuthamangitsidwa kunayamba pa Epulo 27 ndipo kudzatha pa Meyi 22, mkuluyo adauza The Associated Press pofuna kusadziwika chifukwa mgwirizanowu sunadziwike poyera.

en: They are carried out under Title 42 authority, a public health law that has been used to expel migrants on grounds of preventing spread of COVID-19. Title 42 is due to expire May 23, unless a judge intervenes.
ny: Amachitidwa pansi pa ulamuliro wa Title 42, lamulo la zaumoyo wa anthu lomwe lagwiritsidwa ntchito kuthamangitsa osamuka chifukwa choletsa kufalikira kwa COVID-19. Mutu 42 uyenera kutha pa Meyi 23, pokhapokha woweruza atalowerera.

en: The U.S. and Mexico agreed April 26 to a very limited number of expulsions of Cubans and Nicaraguans, according to a high-level Mexican official who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to comment publicly.
ny: U.S. ndi Mexico anagwirizana pa Epulo 26 ku chiwerengero chochepa kwambiri cha kuthamangitsidwa kwa anthu a ku Cuba ndi Nicaragua, malinga ndi mkulu wina wa ku Mexico yemwe analankhula pofuna kusadziwika chifukwa sanaloledwe kuyankha poyera.

en: It was prompted by higher numbers of migrants from those two countries coming to the U.S. border.
ny: Zinasonkhezeredwa ndi chiŵerengero chachikulu cha osamuka ochokera m'maiko aŵiriwo obwera kumalire a United States.

en: Mexico also took into account that the U.S. government had started processing visas in Cuba again, the official said. Mexico had also begun processing visas for Cubans.
ny: Mexico idaganiziranso kuti boma la United States lidayambiranso kukonza ma visa ku Cuba, mkuluyo adatero. Mexico inayambiranso kukonza ma visa a anthu a ku Cuba.

en: Another Mexican official, also not authorized to comment publicly, confirmed that up to 100 Cubans and 20 Nicaraguans were being expelled from San Diego under Title 42.
ny: Mkulu wina wa ku Mexico, yemwenso sanaloledwe kuyankha poyera, adatsimikizira kuti anthu a ku Cuba zokwana 100 ndi anthu 20 a ku Nicaragua akuthamangitsidwa ku San Diego pansi pa Mutu 42.

en: The U.S. Department of Homeland Security did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
ny: Dipatimenti ya U.S. ya Homeland Security sinayankhe nthawi yomweyo pa pempho la ndemanga.

en: Until last week, Mexico only agreed to take Guatemalans, Hondurans and El Salvadorans — in addition to Mexicans — under Title 42 authority. Other nationalities are subject to Title 42 but costs, strained diplomatic ties and other considerations often make it difficult to send them back to their home countries.
ny: Mpaka sabata yatha, Mexico inangovomera kutenga anthu a ku Guatemala, Hondurans ndi El Salvadorans - kuwonjezera pa anthu a ku Mexico - pansi pa ulamuliro wa Title 42. Mitundu ina imakhala pansi pa Mutu 42 koma ndalama, kugwirizana kwaukadaulo komanso malingaliro ena nthawi zambiri zimapangitsa kuti zikhale zovuta kuwatumiza ku mayiko awo.

en: It's next to impossible for the U.S. to expel migrants to Cuba or Nicaragua because of poor relations with those governments. That has posed a challenge for the Biden administration as more people from those countries seek haven in the United States.
ny: Pafupifupi n'zosatheka kuti dziko la United States lithamangitse anthu osamukira ku Cuba kapena nicaragua chifukwa cha ubale woipa ndi maboma amenewo. Zimenezo zabweretsa chitokoso kwa boma la Biden pamene anthu ambiri ochokera m'mayiko amenewo akufunafuna malo osungirako anthu ku United States.

en: Cubans were stopped by U.S. authorities more than 32,000 times on the Mexican border in March, double the number in February and more than five times October's count, according to U.S. Customs and Border Protection. Nicaragua eased travel restrictions from Cuba in November, making it easier for Cubans to continue by land to the U.S. border. Most enter the U.S. in or near Yuma, Arizona, and Del Rio, Texas.
ny: Anthu a ku Cuba anaimitsidwa ndi akuluakulu a ku United States nthawi zoposa 32,000 kumalire a Mexico mu Marichi, kuwirikiza kawiri chiwerengero mu February ndi kuposa kasanu chiwerengero cha October, malinga ndi Customs and Border Protection ya United States. Nicaragua inachepetsa zoletsa kuyenda kuchokera ku Cuba mu Novembala, zomwe zinapangitsa kuti anthu a ku Cuba apitirize mosavuta pamtunda mpaka kumalire a United States. Ambiri amalowa ku US mu kapena pafupi ndi Yuma, Arizona, ndi Del Rio, Texas.

en: Nicaraguans were stopped more than 16,000 times in March, more than double September's level. The vast majority enter in South Texas.
ny: Anthu a ku Nicaragua anaimitsidwa nthawi zoposa 16,000 mu March, kuposa kawiri mlingo wa September. Ambiri amalowa ku South Texas.

en: Lifting Title 42 has proved controversial as midterm elections near, even for Biden's Democratic Party, amid concerns that the U.S. is unprepared for an anticipated increase in migrants seeking asylum. Authorities stopped migrants more than 221,000 times in March, the highest mark in 22 years.
ny: Kukweza Mutu 42 kwatsimikizira kukhala kotsutsana pamene chisankho chapakati chikuyandikira, ngakhale chipani cha Biden's Democratic Party, pakati pa nkhawa kuti dziko la United States silikukonzekera kuwonjezeka koyembekezeredwa kwa osamuka omwe akufuna chitetezo. Akuluakulu a boma anaimitsa anthu osamuka nthawi zoposa 221,000 mu March, chizindikiro chachikulu kwambiri m'zaka 22.

en: The White House and Homeland Security Department have publicly stood behind the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's decision to end the measure because it could no longer be justified on grounds of protecting public health.
ny: Dipatimenti ya White House ndi Homeland Security yaima poyera kumbuyo kwa chisankho cha Centers for Disease Control and Prevention kuti athetse njirayi chifukwa sizingathekenso kulungamitsidwa chifukwa choteteza thanzi la anthu.

en: But the practice of expelling Cubans and Nicaraguans runs counter to the administration's public statements that it was phasing out use of the pandemic powers to prepare for May 23.
ny: Koma mchitidwe wothamangitsa anthu a ku Cuba ndi a ku Nicaragua umatsutsana ndi mawu a boma poyera kuti anali phasing kugwiritsa ntchito mphamvu za mliri kukonzekera May 23.

en: The U.S. has expelled migrants more than 1.8 million times under Title 42 authority since March 2020, effectively overriding rights to seek asylum under U.S. law and international treaty. In doing so, migrants are not subject to immigration law, which include rights to seek protection from persecution at home.
ny: U.S. yathamangitsa osamuka nthawi zoposa 1.8 miliyoni pansi pa ulamuliro wa Title 42 kuyambira March 2020, kugonjetsa bwino ufulu wofunafuna chitetezo pansi pa malamulo a United States ndi mgwirizano wa mayiko. Pochita zimenezi, anthu osamukira kudziko lina sakuyang'aniridwa ndi lamulo losamuka, lomwe limaphatikizapo ufulu wofuna chitetezo ku chizunzo kunyumba.

en: The administration said in court filings that it began processing more Central American adults under immigration laws after the CDC's announcement on April 1. But a federal judge in Louisiana ruled last week that it couldn't start unwinding Title 42 while it was still in effect.
ny: Ulamulirowu unanena m'maofesi a khoti kuti unayamba kukonza anthu ambiri akuluakulu a ku Central America pansi pa malamulo a kusamuka pambuyo pa chilengezo cha CDC pa Epulo 1. Koma woweruza wa boma ku Louisiana anagamula sabata yatha kuti sangayambe kumasula Mutu 42 pamene ukugwirabe ntchito.

en: U.S. District Judge Robert Summerhays strongly criticized the CDC's decision, suggesting he would try to keep Title 42 in effect after May 23. A hearing is scheduled May 13 for oral arguments.
ny: Woweruza wa chigawo cha United States Robert Summerhays adatsutsa kwambiri chigamulo cha CDC, akupereka lingaliro kuti adzayesa kusunga Mutu 42 pambuyo pa Meyi 23. Kuzenga mlandu kwalinganizidwa pa May 13 kaamba ka mikangano ya pakamwa.

en: Marisa Limon, senior director of advocacy and planning at the Hope Border Institute, said advocates began learning about expulsions of Cubans and Nicaraguans from El Paso on Monday and later confirmed the new practice with U.S. officials.
ny: Marisa Limon, mtsogoleri wamkulu wothandizira ndi kukonzekera ku Hope Border Institute, adati othandizira adayamba kuphunzira za kuthamangitsidwa kwa anthu a ku Cuba ndi Nicaragua kuchokera ku El Paso Lolemba ndipo pambuyo pake adatsimikizira mchitidwe watsopano ndi akuluakulu a United States.

en: Limon said the administration is "trying to get every last bit out of Title 42" before it expires. She called it "sobering" but consistent with the administration's efforts to have other countries in the Western hemisphere take more responsibility for hosting people fleeing their homes.
ny: Limon adati boma "likuyesera kupeza chilichonse chomaliza kuchokera ku Title 42" lisanathe. Iye adaitcha "zochititsa chidwi" koma zogwirizana ndi zoyesayesa za boma kuti mayiko ena ku Western hemisphere atenge udindo wambiri wolandira anthu othawa m'nyumba zawo.

en: Mexico Relocates Migrant Camp; Haitians Appear at Border
ny: Mexico Imasamutsira Msasa Wosamukira; Anthu a ku Haiti Akuwonekera pa Malire

en: Mexican authorities said Tuesday they have relocated a migrant camp that sprung up in a park in the border city of Reynosa, moving about 2,000 people from Central America and Haiti to a shelter in the city, across the border from McAllen, Texas.
ny: Akuluakulu a ku Mexico adati Lachiwiri adasamutsira msasa wosamuka womwe unabuka m'paki mumzinda wa Reynosa womwe uli kumalire, kusuntha anthu pafupifupi 2,000 kuchokera ku Central America ndi Haiti kupita kumalo osungirako anthu mumzindawu, kudutsa malire kuchokera ku McAllen, Texas.

en: The camp of migrants mainly from Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras and Haiti sprung up after U.S. officials, citing the pandemic, invoked a health rule that denies migrants a chance to seek asylum.
ny: Msasa wa anthu osamuka makamaka ochokera ku Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras ndi Haiti unabuka pambuyo poti akuluakulu a dziko la United States, potchula za mliriwu, adaitanitsa lamulo la zaumoyo lomwe limakana anthu osamuka mwayi wofunafuna chitetezo.

en: Mexico's National Immigration Institute said the migrants were taken around midnight Monday to the shelter, which it said will have better hygiene and food services.
ny: Bungwe la National Immigration Institute ku Mexico linanena kuti osamukawo adatengedwa pakati pa usiku Lolemba kupita ku malo ogona, omwe adati adzakhala ndi ukhondo wabwino komanso ntchito za chakudya.

en: But on Monday, people in another border city, Nuevo Laredo, said hundreds of migrants, mainly Haitians, have streamed into that city, which is across the border from Laredo, Texas
ny: Koma Lolemba, anthu mumzinda wina wa malire, Nuevo Laredo, adati mazana ambiri a osamuka, makamaka a ku Haiti, ayenda mumzinda umenewo, womwe uli kudutsa malire kuchokera ku Laredo, Texas

en: The rush apparently started after the U.S. began processing some asylum-seekers there.
ny: Kuthamanga kumeneko mwachiwonekere kunayamba pambuyo poti dziko la United States linayamba kukonza anthu ena ofuna kupulumutsidwa kumeneko.

en: The Catholic bishop of Nuevo Laredo said Monday that migrant shelters there are overcrowded, with some migrants sleeping outside in tents.
ny: Bishopu wa Katolika wa Nuevo Laredo adati Lolemba kuti malo osungirako anthu osamuka kumeneko ndi odzaza, ndipo anthu ena osamuka akugona panja m'mahema.

en: Bishop Enrique Sánchez Martínez said migrants started streaming into Nuevo Laredo in late April, though the city isn't usually popular among migrants, in part because it is dominated by the violent Northeast drug cartel.
ny: Bishopu Enrique Sánchez Martínez adati osamuka adayamba kusonkhana ku Nuevo Laredo kumapeto kwa mwezi wa April, ngakhale kuti mzindawu nthawi zambiri suli wotchuka pakati pa osamuka, mwapang'ono chifukwa chakuti umakhala ndi chiwawa cha Northeast mankhwala osokoneza bongo.

en: "It is new for us because this is the last place they come, due to the conditions of our border, of our city, which are sometimes adverse for migrants," the bishop said. "But since they opened the door in the United States to asylum requests, a lot of them came in large groups."
ny: "Ndi zatsopano kwa ife chifukwa iyi ndi malo otsiriza omwe amabwera, chifukwa cha mikhalidwe ya malire athu, ya mzinda wathu, yomwe nthawi zina imakhala yoipa kwa osamuka," adatero bishopu. "Koma popeza anatsegula chitseko ku United States ku zopempha za chitetezo, ambiri a iwo anabwera m'magulu akuluakulu."

en: Marvin Ajic, the director of the Casa Nazareth shelter, said that around April 16, Mexican authorities notified the shelters that the United States would resume processing asylum claims for humanitarian reasons.
ny: Marvin Ajic, yemwe ndi mkulu wa malo osungirako anthu ku Casa Nazareth, ananena kuti cha m'ma April 16, akuluakulu a boma la Mexico anadziwitsa anthu kuti dziko la United States lidzayambiranso kukonza zofuna za anthu othawa kwawo pazifukwa zothandiza anthu.

en: The U.S. had begun allowing more people in, especially Central American adults, to prepare for lifting Title 42 — a pandemic-era health rule that denies migrants a chance to enter the U.S. seek asylum — on May 23. But a federal judge in Louisiana ruled last week that the government could not unwind the rule before the end date.
ny: U.S. idayamba kulola anthu ambiri kulowa, makamaka akuluakulu a ku Central America, kukonzekera kuchotsa Mutu 42 - lamulo la zaumoyo la nthawi ya mliri lomwe limakana osamuka mwayi wolowa ku US kufunafuna chitetezo - pa Meyi 23. Koma woweruza wa boma ku Louisiana anagamula sabata yatha kuti boma silingathe kumasula lamuloli tsiku lomaliza lisanafike.

en: "The (Mexican) immigration officials organized things with the shelters, and the plan was to send people who had been waiting a long time, without any checks, basically anyone," Ajic said.
ny: "Akuluakulu oyang'anira alendo (a ku Mexico) anakonza zinthu ndi malo osungirako anthu, ndipo dongosolo linali kutumiza anthu omwe akhala akudikirira nthawi yayitali, popanda macheke alionse, kwenikweni aliyense," adatero Ajic.

en: That apparently drew the attention of other migrants, including Haitians.
ny: Zikuoneka kuti zimenezi zinachititsa chidwi anthu ena ochokera m'mayiko ena, kuphatikizapo anthu a ku Haiti.

en: In September, similar rumors sparked a rush by about 15,000 mostly Haitian refugees to the Texas border, where they camped under a bridge. U.S. officials began large scale deportations of Haitians while also allowing thousands to remain in the U.S.
ny: Mu September, mphekesera zofananazo zinayambitsa kuthamanga kwa anthu pafupifupi 15,000 makamaka othaŵa kwawo a ku Haiti kupita kumalire a Texas, kumene anamanga msasa pansi pa mlatho. Akuluakulu a dziko la United States anayamba kuthamangitsidwa kwakukulu kwa anthu a ku Haiti pomwe analolanso kuti anthu zikwizikwi akhalebe ku United States.

en: Ajic warned migrants against coming to the border, noting the risks. On Monday, Mexico's National Immigration Institute said that so far this year, it has pulled the bodies of 19 immigrants from the Rio Grande, also known as the Rio Bravo.
ny: Ajic anachenjeza osamuka kuti asabwere kumalire, akuwona zoopsa. Lolemba, bungwe la National Immigration Institute ku Mexico linanena kuti pakadali pano chaka chino, lakoka mitembo ya anthu 19 ochokera ku Rio Grande, yomwe imadziwikanso kuti Rio Bravo.

en: New US Rule Grants Automatic Work Permit Extensions to Noncitizens
ny: Lamulo Latsopano la US Limapereka Chilolezo cha Ntchito Yokhazikika ku Noncitizens

en: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) announced Tuesday that it would automatically extend for 360 days the work permits of immigrants who applied to renew their work authorization amid the current backlog in processing times.
ny: U.S. Unzika ndi Immigration Services (USCIS) analengeza Lachiwiri kuti adzakhala basi kuwonjezera kwa masiku 360 ntchito chilolezo cha alendo amene anafunsira kukonzanso chilolezo chawo ntchito pakati backlog panopa mu nthawi processing.

en: The new notice expands on the 180-day extension USCIS announced in November. It is expected to prevent about 260,000 immigrants from losing their work permits in the next 18 months. It will also give the agency extra time to clear applicants waiting in line, the agency said in a statement.
ny: Chidziwitso chatsopano chikukula pa masiku 180 owonjezera USCIS adalengeza mu November. Zikuyembekezeka kulepheretsa anthu pafupifupi 260,000 ochokera m'mayiko ena kutaya chilolezo chawo chogwira ntchito m'miyezi 18 yotsatira. Zidzapatsanso bungweli nthawi yowonjezera kuti lichotse ofunsira omwe akudikirira pamzere, bungweli linatero m'mawu.

en: "This temporary rule will provide those noncitizens otherwise eligible for the automatic extension an opportunity to maintain employment and provide critical support for their families while avoiding further disruption for U.S. employers," USCIS Director Ur M. Jaddou said in a statement.
ny: "Lamulo lakanthawi limeneli lidzapereka anthu omwe si nzika mwinamwake oyenerera kuwonjezera zokha mwayi wosunga ntchito ndikupereka chithandizo chovuta kwa mabanja awo pamene akupewa kusokonezeka kwina kwa olemba ntchito ku United States," Mtsogoleri wa USCIS M. Jaddou wanu adanena m'mawu.

en: The extension, which takes effect Wednesday, aims to stabilize operations for U.S. employers and help people with pending employment authorizations who have a job and are working in the U.S.
ny: Kuwonjezera, komwe kumagwira ntchito Lachitatu, cholinga chake ndikukhazikitsa ntchito kwa olemba ntchito ku US ndikuthandiza anthu omwe ali ndi chilolezo chodikirira ntchito omwe ali ndi ntchito ndipo akugwira ntchito ku US.

en: USCIS is the agency in charge of handling the nation's immigration paperwork. In recent years, it has struggled with backlogs, an issue made worse by the COVID-19 pandemic and budget shortfalls.
ny: USCIS ndi bungwe loyang'anira kusamalira mapepala a mtundu wa alendo. M'zaka zaposachedwapa, yalimbana ndi backlogs, nkhani yomwe idaipitsidwa ndi mliri wa COVID-19 komanso kuchepa kwa bajeti.

en: In April, Jaddou told U.S. government officials during a congressional hearing that USCIS had 8.5 million pending immigration cases, including those seeking green cards and U.S. naturalization.
ny: Mu Epulo, Jaddou adauza akuluakulu a boma la United States panthawi yomvetsera msonkhano kuti USCIS inali ndi 8.5 miliyoni omwe akuyembekezera milandu yolowera, kuphatikizapo omwe akufuna makadi obiriwira komanso chibadwidwe cha US.

en: She said more than half of those pending cases were taking longer than the agency's normal processing times.
ny: Iye adati oposa theka la milandu yomwe ikuyembekezeredwayo ikutenga nthawi yaitali kuposa nthawi yabwino yomwe bungweli limakonza.

en: Asylum-seekers, immigrants adjusting their status to permanent residence and other noncitizens going through the U.S. immigration process are among the noncitizens affected by the latest work authorization extension.
ny: Anthu ofuna kupulumutsidwa, alendo omwe akusintha udindo wawo kuti akhale okhazikika komanso anthu ena omwe si nzika omwe akudutsa ndondomeko yolowera ku United States ali pakati pa anthu omwe si nzika omwe akukhudzidwa ndi kuwonjezeka kwaposachedwa kwa chilolezo cha ntchito.

en: The agency had reported that processing times for asylum applicants looking to renew work permits increased from seven months in 2017 to 11 months in 2021.
ny: Bungweli linanena kuti nthawi zokonzekera anthu ofuna kupulumutsidwa omwe akuyang'ana kukonzanso zilolezo za ntchito zinawonjezeka kuchokera ku miyezi isanu ndi iwiri mu 2017 mpaka miyezi 11 mu 2021.

en: In March, USCIS announced a program to reduce backlogs, including the expansion of premium processing for certain applications where applicants could pay a higher fee to expedite paperwork processing.
ny: Mu March, USCIS analengeza pulogalamu kuchepetsa backlogs, kuphatikizapo kuwonjezeka kwa processing umafunika ntchito zina kumene ofunsira akhoza kulipira ndalama apamwamba expedite mapepala processing.

en: According to the USCIS, most of the announced changes simply restore options offered before the Trump administration's slowdown of USCIS processing and before the COVID-19 pandemic further slowed the agency's resources.
ny: Malinga ndi USCIS, kusintha kwakukulu komwe kunalengezedwa kumangobwezeretsa njira zomwe zimaperekedwa pamaso pa boma la Trump la USCIS processing komanso mliri wa COVID-19 usanachepetsenso chuma cha bungwe.

en: "For several years, USCIS has been in a precarious financial situation that has impaired the efficient completion of caseloads. The COVID-19 pandemic exacerbated these challenges in 2020, in addition to a hiring freeze and furlough threat leading to workforce attrition and severely reduced capacity. In 2021, before USCIS could recover from these fiscal and operational impacts, there was a sudden and dramatic increase in EAD (Employment Authorization Document) initial and renewal filings," according to the USCIS statement.
ny: "Kwa zaka zingapo, USCIS yakhala mu mkhalidwe wovuta wa zachuma womwe wasokoneza kumaliza bwino kwa milandu. Mliri wa COVID-19 unawonjezera mavuto awa mu 2020, kuwonjezera pa kulemba ntchito kuzizira ndi chiwopsezo cha furlough chomwe chimatsogolera ku attrition ya antchito ndi kuchepa kwakukulu kwa mphamvu. Mu 2021, USCIS isanayambe kuchira kuchokera ku zotsatira zachuma ndi ntchito izi, panali kuwonjezeka kwadzidzidzi komanso kwakukulu kwa EAD (Employment Authorization Document) mafayilo oyambirira ndi kukonzanso, "malinga ndi mawu a USCIS.

en: The USCIS historically has been underfunded because most of the agency's funding comes from application fees that have stalled at $5 billion a year since 2019.
ny: Mbiri yakale ya USCIS yakhala ikuperewera chifukwa ndalama zambiri za bungweli zimachokera ku ndalama zofunsira zomwe zaima pa $ 5 biliyoni pachaka kuyambira 2019.

en: What Is the US-Launched 'Uniting for Ukraine' Program?
ny: Kodi Pulogalamu ya US-Launched 'Uniting for Ukraine' Ndi Chiyani?

en: U.S. President Joe Biden recently announced the Uniting for Ukraine program, which aims to streamline the process for Ukrainians who have fled their country and are seeking safety in the United States.
ny: Pulezidenti wa United States Joe Biden posachedwapa adalengeza pulogalamu ya Uniting for Ukraine, yomwe cholinga chake ndikuwongolera ndondomeko ya anthu aku Ukraine omwe athawa m'dziko lawo ndipo akufuna chitetezo ku United States.

en: The new program, which took effect Monday, will complement existing legal pathways available to those fleeing Russian aggression due to the ongoing Russia-Ukraine crisis, Biden administration officials said.
ny: Pulogalamu yatsopanoyi, yomwe adayamba kugwira ntchito Lolemba, idzakwaniritsa njira zamalamulo zomwe zilipo zomwe zilipo kwa omwe akuthawa kuukira kwa Russia chifukwa cha vuto la Russia-Ukraine lomwe likuchitika, akuluakulu a boma la Biden adati.

en: "The U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) will continue to provide relief to the Ukrainian people, while supporting our European allies who have shouldered so much as the result of Russia's brutal invasion of Ukraine," Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas said in a statement to reporters on April 21.
ny: "Dipatimenti ya U.S. ya Homeland Security (DHS) ipitilizabe kupereka chithandizo kwa anthu aku Ukraine, pomwe akuthandizira anzathu a ku Ulaya omwe anyamula kwambiri chifukwa cha kuwukira kwankhanza kwa Russia ku Ukraine," Mlembi wa Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas adanena m'mawu kwa atolankhani pa Epulo 21.

en: What is Uniting for Ukraine?
ny: Kodi Uniting kwa Ukraine?

en: The program allows U.S. citizens and residents to sponsor Ukrainian refugees under different immigration statuses. The online portal, open to potential sponsors or organizations, is accepting applications and has received more than 4,000 requests so far, CNN reported.
ny: Pulogalamuyi imalola nzika za ku United States ndi nzika kuthandizira othawa kwawo ku Ukraine pansi pa malo osiyanasiyana olembetsa. Chipata cha pa intaneti, chotseguka kwa othandizira kapena mabungwe, chikulandira zofunsira ndipo chalandira zopempha zoposa 4,000 mpaka pano, CNN inanena.

en: Who qualifies under the program?  Ukrainians, or an immediate family member of a Ukrainian citizen. They must have a U.S. sponsor and have been a resident of Ukraine as of February 11.
ny: Ndani amayenerera pansi pa pulogalamuyi?  Anthu a ku Ukraine, kapena wachibale wapafupi wa nzika ya ku Ukraine. Ayenera kukhala ndi wothandizira wa US ndipo akhala akukhala ku Ukraine kuyambira pa February 11.

en: What are the requirements?   They must pass security checks — including a fingerprint and an FBI name check and biographic and biometric screening — and meet public health requirements, such as having the proper vaccinations, before entering the U.S.
ny: Kodi zofunika zake n'zotani?   Ayenera kupita kukafufuza chitetezo — kuphatikizapo kufufuza zala ndi dzina la FBI ndi kufufuza mbiri ya munthu ndi biometric — ndi kukwaniritsa zofunika za umoyo wa anthu, monga ngati kukhala ndi katemera woyenera, asanalowe mu U.S.

en: Those approved will be allowed to travel to the U.S., be considered for humanitarian parole on a case-by-case basis, stay in the country for two years, and apply for work permits.
ny: Omwe avomerezedwa adzaloledwa kupita ku US, kulingaliridwa kuti athandizidwe pa mlandu uliwonse, kukhala m'dzikoli kwa zaka ziwiri, ndikufunsira chilolezo cha ntchito.

en: "The United States strongly encourages Ukrainians seeking refuge in the United States who do not have and are not eligible for a visa to seek entry via Uniting for Ukraine from Europe. This will be the safest and most efficient way to pursue temporary refuge in the United States," a DHS statement said.
ny: "United States imalimbikitsa kwambiri anthu a ku Ukraine omwe akufuna kuthawira ku United States omwe alibe ndipo sali oyenerera visa kuti afunefune kulowa kudzera mu Uniting for Ukraine kuchokera ku Ulaya. Iyi idzakhala njira yotetezeka komanso yothandiza kwambiri yotsata malo othawira kwakanthawi ku United States," mawu a DHS adatero.

en: Who qualifies as a sponsor?
ny: Ndani amayenerera kukhala wothandizira?

en: U.S. citizens and other residents who hold lawful status in the United States or who are beneficiaries of Deferred Enforced Departure, Temporary Protected Status, or Deferred Action, among others.
ny: Nzika za ku United States ndi nzika zina zomwe zimakhala ndi udindo wovomerezeka ku United States kapena zomwe zimapindula ndi Deferred Enforced Departure, Temporary Protected Status, kapena Deferred Action, pakati pa ena.

en: Sponsors will be required to prove they can financially support the refugee while they are in the U.S. They also need to pass security and background vetting "to protect against exploitation and abuse." The Ukrainian applicant will receive authorization only after everything is verified, including that the sponsor has the means to support them while they are in the U.S.
ny: Othandizira adzafunikira kutsimikizira kuti angathandize ndalama othawa kwawo pamene ali ku U.S. Amafunikanso kupititsa chitetezo ndi kufufuza zam'mbuyo "kuteteza ku kudyeredwa masuku pamutu ndi nkhanza." Wofunsira wa ku Ukraine adzalandira chilolezo pokhapokha chirichonse chitatsimikiziridwa, kuphatikizapo kuti wothandizira ali ndi njira zowathandizira pamene ali ku US.

en: Who is not eligible for parole under the program?
ny: Ndani amene sali woyenera kumasulidwa pansi pa pulogalamuyi?

en: Ukrainian citizens already in the U.S. are not eligible for parole under Uniting for Ukraine.
ny: Nzika za ku Ukraine zomwe zili kale ku US sizili zoyenera kumasulidwa pansi pa Uniting for Ukraine.

en: However, they can apply for Temporary Protected Status, which is another form of humanitarian relief that allows people to legally stay and work in the U.S.
ny: Komabe, akhoza kupempha mkhalidwe wotetezedwa kwakanthawi, womwe ndi mtundu wina wa chithandizo chothandizira anthu chomwe chimalola anthu kukhala mwalamulo ndikugwira ntchito ku US.

en: What about those arriving at the U.S.-Mexico border?
ny: Nanga bwanji amene akufika kumalire a dziko la United States ndi Mexico?

en: Citing safety issues, U.S. officials have urged Ukrainians not to travel to Mexico in hopes of entering the United States. In addition, U.S. Customs and Border Protection has no place to hold them while they go through the Uniting for Ukraine vetting process.
ny: Potchula nkhani za chitetezo, akuluakulu a dziko la United States adalimbikitsa anthu a ku Ukraine kuti asapite ku Mexico poyembekezera kulowa ku United States. Kuphatikiza apo, U.S. Customs and Border Protection ilibe malo oti awagwire pamene akudutsa ndondomeko ya Uniting for Ukraine vetting.

en: Since Uniting for Ukraine's launch on Monday, Ukrainians who arrive at U.S. ports of entry without a valid visa or without preauthorization to travel to the United States through the Uniting for Ukraine program will be denied entry and told to apply to the program.
ny: Popeza Uniting kwa Ukraine kukhazikitsidwa Lolemba, Ukraine amene amafika ku madoko US kulowa popanda visa chomveka kapena popanda preauthorization kupita ku United States kudzera Uniting kwa Ukraine pulogalamu adzakanizidwa kulowa ndipo anauzidwa kuti ntchito pulogalamu.

en: Biden officials hope this will curb the number of Ukrainian migrants seeking humanitarian parole along the border.
ny: Akuluakulu a Biden akuyembekeza kuti izi zidzathetsa chiwerengero cha anthu osamukira ku Ukraine omwe akufuna chithandizo cha anthu m'mphepete mwa malire.

en: Those at the border must apply under the rules of Uniting for Ukraine, meaning they must have a qualifying sponsor or a non-government agency willing to sponsor them in the U.S. for up to two years. And they need to have all required vaccinations and pass background checks.
ny: Omwe ali kumalire ayenera kugwira ntchito pansi pa malamulo a Uniting for Ukraine, kutanthauza kuti ayenera kukhala ndi wothandizira woyenerera kapena bungwe losakhala la boma lofunitsitsa kuwathandiza ku US mpaka zaka ziwiri. Ndipo ayenera kukhala ndi katemera yense wofunikira ndi kufufuza mbiri yawo.

en: The Biden administration announced the private sponsorship initiative as another way the U.S. hopes to achieve President Biden's commitment to welcome up to 100,000 Ukrainians displaced by the Russian military invasion.
ny: Ulamuliro wa Biden unalengeza ndondomeko yothandizira payekha ngati njira ina yomwe dziko la United States likuyembekeza kukwaniritsa kudzipereka kwa Purezidenti Biden kuti alandire anthu a ku Ukraine mpaka 100,000 omwe athamangitsidwa ndi kuwukira kwa asilikali a Russia.

en: As of Thursday, almost 5.4 million refugees have since left Ukraine, according to U.N. data.
ny: Kuyambira Lachinayi, pafupifupi 5.4 miliyoni othawa kwawo achoka ku Ukraine, malinga ndi deta ya UN.

en: Report: Rwanda Should Ease Restrictions On 2003 National Elections - 2001-10-15
ny: Lipoti: Rwanda Iyenera Kuchepetsa Zoletsa Pa Zisankho za Dziko la 2003 - 2001-10-15

en: In 2003 Rwanda will hold its first national elections since the 1994 genocide. A new report says the government of Rwanda needs to relax its control over public life if the polls are to have any credibility.
ny: M'chaka cha 2003 dziko la Rwanda lidzachita chisankho chake choyamba m'dziko lonse kuyambira pamene anthu anapha anthu mu 1994. Lipoti latsopano likuti boma la Rwanda likuyenera kupeputsa ulamuliro wake pa moyo wa anthu ngati mavoti akufuna kukhala ndi chidaliro chilichonse.

en: There was relief when the Rwandan Patriotic Front seized power in Rwanda in 1994, ending the genocide in which about 800,000 minority Tutsis and moderate Hutus were killed.
ny: Panali mpumulo pamene gulu la Rwandan Patriotic Front linalanda ulamuliro ku Rwanda mu 1994, kuthetsa kupululutsa fuko kumene Atutsi ochepa pafupifupi 800,000 ndi Ahutu achikatikati anaphedwa.

en: The new military government promised to restore democracy to Rwanda via elections in 2003.
ny: Boma latsopano lankhondo linalonjeza kubwezeretsa demokalase ku Rwanda kudzera pa zisankho mu 2003.

en: That process began in March this year, with district elections.
ny: Ndondomeko imeneyo inayamba mu March chaka chino, ndi chisankho cha chigawo.

en: Senior analyst Francois Grignon, of the International Crisis Group, a Brussels-based policy research organization, says he was disappointed with the district poll. Mr. Grignon says the process was so tightly controlled that he maintains no genuine opposition candidates were allowed to stand.
ny: Katswiri wamkulu Francois Grignon, wa International Crisis Group, bungwe lofufuza ndondomeko ku Brussels, akuti adakhumudwa ndi kafukufuku wa chigawo. Bambo Grignon akuti ndondomekoyi inali yolamulidwa mwamphamvu kwambiri moti akusunga kuti palibe otsutsa enieni omwe analoledwa kuima.

en: "There was a screening and there was a preparation of the elections, which did not allow other candidates than those who had been rubber-stamped by the government to actually contest, especially for the executive positions within the local authorities," he says. "If consensual democracy means that the political debate is actually handled before the electoral contest in such a way that it does not lead to a real competition then there is no democracy at all."
ny: "Panali kuyezetsa ndipo panali kukonzekera kwa zisankho, zomwe sizinalole ena omwe akufuna kuchita chisankho kusiyana ndi omwe boma linawasindikiza ndi mphira kuti azipikisanadi, makamaka maudindo akuluakulu mkati mwa akuluakulu am'deralo," iye akutero. "Ngati demokalase yovomerezeka imatanthauza kuti mkangano wandale umasamalidwadi mpikisano wa chisankho usanachitike m'njira yoti usayambitse mpikisano weniweni ndiye kuti palibe demokalase ngakhale pang'ono."

en: In a new report, titled Consensual Democracy in Post Genocide Rwanda, the International Crisis Group urges the international community to pressure Rwanda's government to liberalize political activity.
ny: Mu lipoti latsopano, lotchedwa Consensual Democracy in Post Genocide Rwanda, bungwe la International Crisis Group likulimbikitsa mayiko a padziko lonse kukakamiza boma la Rwanda kuti limasula ntchito zandale.

en: The report notes that the military dominates public life and there is little open criticism of the government, either in the media or by opposition figures.
